raw_text:
CSA 'could close', says minister
 
 Ministers would not rule out scrapping the Child Support Agency if it failed to improve, Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson has warned.
 
 But he said replacing the controversial CSA would be "the nuclear option". A report by the Commons work and pensions committee called for the agency to be wound up unless it improved its service within weeks. Chairman Sir Archy Kirkwood said: "If the agency cannot be rescued, then it must be replaced."
 
 The committee reached its conclusions after it found that nearly 250,000 cases have yet to be processed. It warned that it could be five years before the CSA was "fit for purpose", describing it as "a failing organisation" and "in crisis" with parents facing payment delays and inaccurate maintenance calculations. The report urged the CSA to draw up contingency plans, including the "abandonment option", to be presented to Parliament by Easter, in case the CS2 computer system could not be made to work.
 
 And responding to calls for the agency to be scrapped, Mr Johnson told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "I certainly wouldn't rule out the nuclear option of moving to a completely new system. "But I think the select committee would agree with me we would only do that when we were absolutely convinced that this system just isn't going to work."
 
 The MPs launched their inquiry into the CSA's performance after it became clear that, despite the introduction of a simpler system of calculating maintenance payments for new cases in 2003, a backlog of claims was building up. The MPs found the £456m system from American IT giant EDS was "nowhere near being fully functional and the number of dissatisfied, disenchanted and angry customers continues to escalate". Faced with the committee's criticism, the government has suspended its plan to cut the agency's staff by 25%. The CSA has been surrounded in controversy since its introduction in 1993 to assess and enforce child support payments by absent parents.
 
 It is currently chasing outstanding payments of more than £720m, while a further £947m has been designated as "unrecoverable".
 
 Michelle, a mother of twins, said she had not received a penny of the £57 a week she should be receiving from her ex-partner and had faced an "on-going battle" with the CSA. Her forms have twice been lost in the post, she said. "I don't receive correspondence, I don't receive phone calls, I have to chase them all the time," she said. Theresa May, Tory shadow work and pensions secretary, said: "We have got to find a way that's going to ensure those payments get through to the people who are due them." The agency's former chief executive Doug Smith quit last autumn claiming he was "seriously disappointed" with its performance. The committee said the National Audit Office should investigate why the EDS system had gone so badly wrong. It blamed the agency's senior management for a "multitude of problems" within the agency, including for an apparent lack of training of frontline staff.
llama3.2:1b: Ministers have warned that the Child Support Agency (CSA) could be closed if it fails to improve its service.
The agency has been found to be in crisis with nearly 250,000 cases still pending and a backlog of payments totaling £720m.
A report by the Commons work and pensions committee urged the agency to be replaced or wound up due to its poor performance.
llama3.2:3b: Minister Alan Johnson warns that the Child Support Agency could be closed if it fails to improve, calling replacing it the "nuclear option".
A report by MPs says the agency is in crisis, with nearly 250,000 cases unprocessed and a five-year timeline to fix issues.
The CSA has been criticized for its performance since introduction in 1993, including a £456m system from EDS being "nowhere near fully functional".
gemma2:2b: The Child Support Agency (CSA) is facing criticism and calls to be replaced due to its failure to process claims efficiently, leading to delays and inaccurate calculations.
The Commons work and pensions committee recommended replacing the CSA unless it improves within weeks.
Despite suspending plans to cut staff by 25%, the government considers the possibility of a complete new system as a last resort.

The CSA faces challenges with outstanding payments totaling over £720 million and another £947 million deemed uncollectible, leading to user frustration like Michelle's case where she hasn't received child support.
There are calls for action to ensure timely payment to parents who deserve it.

Key points:

- Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson warns that replacing CSA could be considered as "the nuclear option"
- The CSAR had been in operation since 1993, but faced a backlog of claims
- MPs launched inquiry into the agency's performance after it was revealed they were facing issues with its calculations
- The CSA has over £720m outstanding and some £947m is designated as "unrecoverable"
- Michelle Smith quit due to disappointment in her experience with the agency
- The CSAR had been in operation since 1993 but faced a backlog of claims

The agency faces delays in processing nearly 250,000 cases and is accused of being "a failing organisation" with parents facing payment delays and inaccurate maintenance calculations.
MPs have criticized its complex IT system, which has led to a £456m budget overrun over eight years.
Minister Alan Johnson said he would consider abandoning the agency but only if convinced it can't be fixed.
The CSA is currently chasing outstanding payments of more than £720m and has lost contact with thousands of parents seeking child support.

A Commons work and pensions committee report found nearly 250,000 cases still unresolved, with the CSA described as "a failing organisation" facing payment delays and inaccurate calculations.
The government has suspended plans to cut staff by 25%, amid criticism of an £456m EDS system now deemed insufficiently functional.
MPs suggest abandoning the current system if it fails, citing concerns over parents receiving delayed or incorrect child support payments.
Michelle describes ongoing frustration with the CSA’s service, while Theresa May advocates for ensuring payments reach those due.
Former CSA chief executive Doug Smith resigned in protest at its performance, leading to a call for an investigation into management issues and system failures.

Responding to calls for the agency to be scrapped, Mr Johnson told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "I certainly wouldn't rule out the nuclear option of moving to a completely new system.
But I think the select committee would agree with me we would only do that when we were absolutely sure that this system just isn't going to work."

Faced with the committee's criticism, the government has suspended its plan to cut the agency's staff by 25%.
The CSA has been surrounded in controversy since its introduction in 1993 to assess and enforce child support payments by absent parents.

tinyllama:1.1b: The government has suspended plans to cut the Child Support Agecy (CSA) staff by 25% due to the ongoing controversy surrounding it, and a report by the Work and Pensions Committee called for the agency to be replaced with a new system.
The report also found that nearly 250,000 cases remain unprocessed as the CSAs computer system is still in crisis and parents are facing payment delay and incorrect maintenance calculations.
A minister has warned of scrapping the CSA if it fails to improve service within weeks due to the ongoing controversy.
The MPs launched an inquiry into the CSA's performance, including alleged problems with the EDS system that went wrong, which have led to a backlog of claims and dissatisfied customers.
tinydolphin:1.1b: CSA: Child Support Agency - Minister Discusses Possibility of Closure; Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson Suggests Merging with another Agencies.
The Child Support Agency (CSA) is a vital part of managing payments for child support, but despite significant improvements in recent years, it faces challenges in fulfilling its duties.
The government has been considering various options to address the agency's problems and reduce costs.
One proposal under consideration is the closure of the CSA.
However, Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson has warned against this measure, stating that replacing the controversial Child Support Agency would be a "nuclear option."
A report by the Commons work and pensions committee called for the agency to be wound up unless it improved its service within weeks.
Chairman Sir Archy Kirkwood described the CSA as a "failing organisation" and an "in crisis" with parents facing payment delays and inaccurate maintenance calculations.
The minister's warning suggests that he may reconsider his position on closing the CSA if the agency can improve its performance and provide better service to its customers.
However, there is concern that the agency has not received sufficient attention or investment to meet its goals of reducing payments for child support and improving its service.
The report highlights concerns about the EDS system used by the CSA, which was introduced in 2003 but faced a backlog of claims due to a lack of functionality and dissatisfaction from customers.
Despite this, it is still chasing outstanding payments of more than £720 million, while a further £947 million has been designated as "unrecoverable".
phi:2.7b: The Child Support Agency (CSA) is under scrutiny after the Work and Pensions Committee warns that it could be scrapped if it fails to improve its services.
Ministers are considering abandoning the CSA altogether or replacing it with a new system, but they would only do so when they're sure the current one won't work.
The agency's controversial computer system has been in crisis for years, causing delays and inaccurate maintenance calculations.
In addition, nearly 250,000 cases have yet to be processed.
The MPs' report also suggests that EDS, the company contracted to develop the CSA system, is responsible for many of the problems.

This comes after a report by the Commons work and pensions committee called for the agency to be wound up unless it improves its service within weeks.
The minister warned that replacing the controversial CSA would be "the nuclear option".
However, the government has suspended its plan to cut the agency's staff by 25%.
The CSA has been surrounded in controversy since its introduction in 1993 to assess and enforce child support payments by absent parents.

stablelm-zephyr:3b: The UK's Work and Pensions Secretary, Alan Johnson, has stated that ministers would not rule out scrapping the Child Support Agency (CSA) if it fails to improve.
The Commons work and pensions committee recently called for the agency to be wound up unless it improved its service within weeks.
A backlog of cases still exists with nearly 250,000 unprocessed cases, and the CSA has been described as "a failing organisation" and "in crisis."
Johnson believes that a new system could be introduced if necessary but would only do so when convinced that it will work.

The government has suspended its plan to cut the agency's staff by 25%, and CSA is currently chasing outstanding payments of over £720 million, with an additional £947 million designated as "unrecoverable."
chatgpt-4o-latest: The UK government has warned that the Child Support Agency (CSA) could be scrapped if it fails to improve, though Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson called this the "nuclear option."
A parliamentary committee found the CSA in crisis, with 250,000 unprocessed cases, inaccurate maintenance calculations, and long delays.
The committee urged contingency plans, including shutting down the agency, if its IT system could not be fixed.
The CSA, introduced in 1993, has struggled with inefficiencies and is chasing £720m in unpaid child support, with £947m deemed unrecoverable.
Critics, including affected parents and opposition politicians, have called for urgent reforms.
The government has suspended planned staff cuts and may consider replacing the agency if improvements are not made.
The committee also urged an investigation into the failure of the CSA’s IT system and blamed senior management for widespread issues.
stablelm2:1.6b: Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson warns that ministers could scrap the Child Support Agency (CSA) if it fails to improve, citing the nuclear option as a last resort.
A report by the Commons work and pensions committee called for the agency to be wound up unless it improves its service within weeks.
The committee found that nearly 90% of cases have yet to be processed and warned it could be five years before the CSA is "fit for purpose."
However, Mr. Johnson stated that he wouldn't rule out a new system if he was certain it would not work.
The CSA has faced controversy since its introduction in 2003, currently chasing over £1 billion worth of outstanding payments and facing issues with the EDS computer system.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The Child Support Agency (CSA) is facing potential closure if it fails to improve its service, according to Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson.

A report by the Commons work and pensions committee, chaired by Sir Archy Kirkwood, deemed the CSA a "failing organization" in crisis due to processing delays, inaccurate calculations, and dissatisfied customers.
Nearly 250,000 cases remain unprocessed, with the report predicting it could take five years for the agency to become functional.
The committee urged the CSA to develop contingency plans, including the "abandonment option," which should be presented to Parliament by Easter.
Despite this, the government has postponed its plan to cut 25% of CSA staff due to the agency's poor performance.
The CSA has a backlog of over £720 million in outstanding payments and an additional £947 million deemed unrecoverable.
Personal accounts from affected individuals, like mother Michelle who hasn't received her child support for twins, highlight ongoing issues with the agency's communication and staffing.
The report criticizes senior management for numerous problems within the CSA, including insufficient training of frontline staff.
